articles.title: Learning feminism before knowing its name: Verse’s story from Myanmar
articles.summary: “Through film, I want people to feel empathy to see women’s emotions, existence, and oppression in new ways. My mind is always thinking for them.”
articles.content:
Exile Hub is one of Global Voices’ partners in Southeast Asia, emerging in response to the 2021 coup in Myanmar, focusing on empowering journalists and human rights defenders. This edited article is republished under a content partnership agreement.

As a Burmese filmmaker shaped by her grandmother’s quiet defiance, Verse uses storytelling to challenge gender bias and uplift women whose voices are too often erased.

Verse began her professional journey in 2018 as a reporter at a local news agency in Myanmar. She dreamed of covering political news, but quickly encountered systemic gender bias. During a major assignment, male reporters were sent to Nay Pyi Taw to cover parliament-related matters, and she was told to stay behind.

She recalled the moment: “I was told women weren’t given those opportunities. I could not accept a workplace that denied my growth simply because I was a woman.”

She left journalism and joined a women’s rights organization, shifting her focus to human rights and feminist advocacy.

Before Verse ever stepped into a newsroom or picked up a camera, she grew up watching her grandmother quietly defy the rules of her time. A tough, respected Rakhine woman running a sawmill business, working daily among men, and refusing to bend to the gender norms imposed on her.

Verse talks about her grandma proudly: “She never once told me, ‘you’re a girl, so you can’t do this.’ She taught me that actions have consequences, but gender should never be a limitation.”

Her grandmother’s philosophy became the backbone of Verse’s feminist worldview. Even in small everyday acts, her grandmother pushed against societal expectations. While the neighborhood insisted women must hide their underwear under the longyi when drying laundry, her grandmother thought differently. From a health perspective, she said underwear needed sunlight to prevent bacteria. So she just hung them in front of the house. She never believed being a woman meant you had less dignity.

Growing up under such influence, Verse absorbed feminism not through books but through lived experience with a woman who modeled resilience, pride, and equality long before Verse learned the word “feminist.”

In 2020, Verse attended Yangon Film School, where she began translating feminist ideas into visual storytelling. The classroom itself became another frontline of gender bias. Six male and six female students attended. One day, a male classmate asked her an inappropriate question rooted in a harmful cultural myth about girls with arm hair or slight mustaches being “sexually provocative.”

She was hurt and angry, but she chose a different response.

During a group discussion in class, Verse brought the incident forward, sparking an honest conversation about how students should respond when they encounter verbal harassment. Her courage led the film school to introduce its first-ever zero-tolerance policy on sexual harassment.

Verse’s filmmaking has since become an extension of her feminist inheritance. Her storytelling centers on women who are often unheard or unseen.

“Through film, I want people to feel empathy to see women’s emotions, existence, and oppression in new ways. My mind is always thinking for them.”

One of her most meaningful works is the animated film “Exit,” portraying the lived experiences of sex workers in Myanmar, who face stigma, violence, and criminalization. Supported by Goethe-Institut Myanmar, the film has been screened at the Shi Exhibition and DVB Peacock Film Festival 2024.

Verse first learned about Exile Hub in 2022 after receiving a Critical Voices production grant. In 2025, she was again selected as a recipient of the Feminist Storytelling Grant, under which she created the documentary “Fight for Freedom.”

The film follows an exiled woman resisting Myanmar military patriarchy, a story of courage, and the fierce determination to spark ideological revolution. There is no hierarchy of oppression in which one form is greater or lesser than another. Every form of oppression must be challenged and dismantled.

Though her professional opportunities have widened, Verse still makes her home in Myanmar. Her grandmother is aging and requires care.

She says simply: “She didn’t just raise me. She taught me my worth. She made sure I never believed my gender was a limitation. How could I ever leave her behind?”

Feminism, for her, is a lived experience grounded in resilience and the courage to challenge oppression wherever it appears. Through her films, Verse honors her belief by reshaping narratives, breaking barriers, and imagining a world where women’s voices are not just heard, but honored.

Verse’s life is shaped by a simple ideology: “Women deserve equality, dignity, and the freedom to define their own lives.”

articles.personality_title: Burmese filmmaker uses stories to challenge gender bias and support women
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In Myanmar, a country where women often face unfair treatment, a young filmmaker named Verse is using movies to show the struggles and strength of women. She grew up inspired by her grandmother, a strong woman who worked hard and refused to accept limits just because she was a woman.

**What happened** – Verse started as a news reporter in 2018 but faced gender discrimination when she was denied important assignments given to male reporters. She left journalism and joined a women’s rights group, then studied film in 2020. At film school, she spoke out against sexist attitudes, helping create a new rule against harassment. She has made films like "Exit," about sex workers’ struggles, and "Fight for Freedom," telling the story of a woman fighting against military control.

**Impact** – Verse’s work gives a voice to women who are often ignored or judged unfairly. Her films help others understand women’s feelings and challenges in Myanmar. She also helped change her film school’s rules, making it safer for female students. Her story shows how one person’s courage can push back against unfair rules and inspire change.

**What’s next step** – Verse continues making films that highlight women’s rights and hopes to reach more people with her stories. She also cares for her grandmother at home, keeping close the lessons of strength and equality she learned. Her work may encourage more young women in Myanmar to stand up for their rights and tell their own stories.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Verse uses filmmaking and her grandmother’s example to fight gender bias and give women in Myanmar a stronger voice through stories that matter.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une réalisatrice birmane utilise le cinéma pour lutter contre les inégalités de genre et soutenir les femmes
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En Birmanie, où les femmes sont souvent traitées injustement, une jeune réalisatrice nommée Verse utilise le cinéma pour montrer les luttes et la force des femmes. Elle a grandi en s'inspirant de sa grand-mère, une femme forte qui travaillait dur et refusait d'accepter des limites juste parce qu'elle était une femme.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Verse a commencé comme journaliste en 2018 mais a fait face à des discriminations de genre quand on lui a refusé des missions importantes données aux hommes. Elle a quitté le journalisme pour rejoindre une organisation de défense des droits des femmes, puis a étudié le cinéma en 2020. À l'école de cinéma, elle a dénoncé des attitudes sexistes, aidant à créer une nouvelle règle contre le harcèlement. Elle a réalisé des films comme "Exit", sur les difficultés des travailleuses du sexe, et "Fight for Freedom", racontant le combat d'une femme contre le contrôle militaire.

**Impact** – Le travail de Verse donne une voix aux femmes souvent ignorées ou jugées injustement. Ses films aident les autres à comprendre les sentiments et les défis des femmes en Birmanie. Elle a aussi contribué à changer les règles de son école de cinéma, la rendant plus sûre pour les étudiantes. Son histoire montre comment le courage d'une personne peut repousser les règles injustes et inspirer le changement.

**Prochaine étape** – Verse continue de réaliser des films qui mettent en lumière les droits des femmes et espère toucher plus de personnes avec ses histoires. Elle prend aussi soin de sa grand-mère à la maison, gardant près d'elle les leçons de force et d'égalité qu'elle a apprises. Son travail pourrait encourager plus de jeunes femmes en Birmanie à défendre leurs droits et à raconter leurs propres histoires.

**Message en une phrase** – Verse utilise le cinéma et l'exemple de sa grand-mère pour combattre les préjugés de genre et donner aux femmes de Birmanie une voix plus forte à travers des histoires importantes.
articles.personality_title_es: Cineasta birmana usa historias para desafiar la desigualdad de género y apoyar a las mujeres
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En Myanmar, un país donde las mujeres a menudo enfrentan trato injusto, una joven cineasta llamada Verse usa películas para mostrar las luchas y la fuerza de las mujeres. Creció inspirada por su abuela, una mujer fuerte que trabajaba duro y no aceptaba límites solo por ser mujer.

**Qué pasó** – Verse comenzó como reportera en 2018, pero enfrentó discriminación de género cuando le negaron asignaciones importantes que sí dieron a reporteros hombres. Dejó el periodismo y se unió a un grupo de derechos de las mujeres, luego estudió cine en 2020. En la escuela de cine, habló contra actitudes sexistas y ayudó a crear una regla contra el acoso. Ha hecho películas como "Exit", sobre las dificultades de trabajadoras sexuales, y "Fight for Freedom", que cuenta la lucha de una mujer contra el control militar.

**Impacto** – El trabajo de Verse da voz a mujeres que a menudo son ignoradas o juzgadas injustamente. Sus películas ayudan a otros a entender los sentimientos y desafíos de las mujeres en Myanmar. También ayudó a cambiar las reglas de su escuela de cine para hacerla más segura para las estudiantes. Su historia muestra cómo el valor de una persona puede enfrentar reglas injustas e inspirar cambios.

**Próximo paso** – Verse sigue haciendo películas que destacan los derechos de las mujeres y espera llegar a más personas con sus historias. También cuida de su abuela en casa, manteniendo cerca las lecciones de fuerza e igualdad que aprendió. Su trabajo puede animar a más jóvenes en Myanmar a defender sus derechos y contar sus propias historias.

**Mensaje en una frase** – Verse usa el cine y el ejemplo de su abuela para luchar contra los prejuicios de género y dar una voz más fuerte a las mujeres en Myanmar a través de historias que importan.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a sturdy, traditional Burmese sawmill beside a gently flowing river, with a strong female silhouette made of interwoven threads rising from the sawmill’s wooden beams, symbolizing resilience and quiet defiance; nearby, clotheslines hold colorful longyi and underwear drying openly in the sun, representing breaking gender norms and health over convention, all rendered in soft, natural earth tones and muted fabrics.
